From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: cãlar and çalar

Catalan

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Latin chalāre.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): (Central, Balearic) [kəˈla]
  • IPA(key): (Valencia) [kaˈlaɾ]
  • Audio (Barcelona):(file)
  • Rhymes: -a(ɾ)

Verb

[edit]

calar (first-person singular present calo, first-person singular preterite calí, past participle calat)

  1. (transitive, archaic) to lower
  2. (transitive, nautical) to lower (sails, masts, ships, nets, etc.)
  3. (transitive) to soak, to drench
  4. (transitive) to insert, to fit together
  5. (transitive) to set, to light (a fire)
    calar foc a ― to set fire to
  6. (reflexive) to stall (of an engine: to stop suddenly)
  7. (transitive) to stall (to cause the engine of a manual-transmission car to stop)

Conjugation

[edit]
    Conjugation of calar (first conjugation)

plural calats calades

vós 		vostès
affirmative — cala cali calem caleu calin
negative (no) — no calis no cali no calem no caleu no calin

Synonyms

[edit]
  • (lower): baixar
  • (lower (sails)): arriar
  • (soak): penetrar

Derived terms

[edit]
  • acalar
  • cala
  • calada
  • calador
  • calament
  • calat
  • calatge

Further reading

[edit]
  • “calar”, in Diccionari de la llengua catalana [Dictionary of the Catalan Language] (in Catalan), second edition, Institute of Catalan Studies [Catalan: Institut d'Estudis Catalans], April 2007
  • “calar”, in Gran Diccionari de la Llengua Catalana, Grup Enciclopèdia Catalana, 2025
  • “calar” in Diccionari normatiu valencià, Acadèmia Valenciana de la Llengua.
  • “calar” in Diccionari català-valencià-balear, Antoni Maria Alcover and Francesc de Borja Moll, 1962.

Galician

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Old Galician-Portuguese, from Latin *callāre, from Latin chalāre, from Ancient Greek χαλάω (khaláō). Cognate with Portuguese calar and Spanish callar.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /kaˈlaɾ/ [kɑˈlaɾ]
  • Rhymes: -aɾ
  • Hyphenation: ca‧lar

Verb

[edit]

calar (first-person singular present calo, first-person singular preterite calei, past participle calado)

  1. (intransitive) to shut up; to be silent
    Calen barbas e falen cartas. (idiom) ― Let the beards [people] be silent and the charters [deeds] speak.
    • 1405, E. Cal Pardo, editor, Colección diplomática medieval do arquivo da catedral de Mondoñedo, Santiago: Consello da Cultura Galega, page 227:
      Et as ditas persoas et coengos respondendo ao dito testemoyo et requerimento que contra elles tomaron os ditos omes moradores en Çesuras et en Çonay sobre rason da dita carta do dito corregidor diseron que a dita carta era de obedesçer et non de conprir por moytas rasoes a primeira por quanto a dita carta foy gaanada calada a uerdade et espremida a falsidade por quanto o dito Garçia Sanches nunca deu tal sentença commo os ditos moradores de Çesuras et de Çonan disen nen se prouaria que y ouuese libelo posto nen pleito concluso nen dia asignado para dar sentença por lo qual a dita carta non era de conprir nen a dita sentença non aueria efecto.
      and said persons and canons, answering that testimony and requirement that against them gave said inhabitants of Cesuras and Zonán, on account of said magistrate's charter, said that the aforementioned charter was of obey but do not fulfil [non executive] for a number of reasons; the first one, because that deed was acquired by silencing the truth and expressing falsehood, because said García Sánchez never gave such a sentence as the inhabitants of Cesuras and Zonán say, nor it could be proven that there were a posted libel, nor a concluded lawsuit, nor a day assigned for giving the sentence, therefore that charter was non executive, nor said sentence could have any effect
  2. (nautical, transitive) to sink, submerge
  3. (nautical, transitive) to touch the bottom
  4. (transitive) to fathom; to probe

Derived terms

[edit]
  • calado

[edit]

Indonesian

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈt͡ʃa.lar/, [ˈt͡ʃa.lar]

Noun

[edit]

calar (plural calar-calar)

  1. scratch
    Synonym: baret
    Kulitnya tertutupi oleh calar-calar kecil.
    Her skin was covered with tiny scratches.

Derived terms

[edit]
  • bercalar
  • calar-balar
  • mencalarkan
  • pencalaran
  • tercalar

Further reading

[edit]
  • “calar”, in Kamus Besar Bahasa Indonesia [Great Dictionary of the Indonesian Language] (in Indonesian), Jakarta: Agency for Language Development and Cultivation – Ministry of Education, Culture, Research, and Technology of the Republic of Indonesia, 2016

Italian

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From calare.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /kaˈlar/
  • Rhymes: -ar
  • Hyphenation: ca‧làr

Noun

[edit]

calar m (invariable)

  1. setting (of a heavenly body)

Derived terms

[edit]
  • calar del sole (“sunset”)
  • calar della luna (“moonset”)

Further reading

[edit]
  • calar in Collins Italian-English Dictionary

Anagrams

[edit]
  • Carla, Clara

Occitan

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Old Occitan [Term?], from Vulgar Latin *calāre or *callāre, from Latin chalāre, from Ancient Greek χαλάω (khaláō).

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • Audio (Béarn):(file)

Verb

[edit]

calar

  1. to shut up (prevent from speaking)

Portuguese

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Vulgar Latin *callāre, from Latin chalāre, from Ancient Greek χαλάω (khaláō).

Pronunciation

[edit]
 
  • (Brazil) IPA(key): /kaˈla(ʁ)/ [kaˈla(h)]
  • (Brazil) IPA(key): /kaˈla(ʁ)/ [kaˈla(h)]
    • (São Paulo) IPA(key): /kaˈla(ɾ)/
    • (Rio de Janeiro) IPA(key): /kaˈla(ʁ)/ [kaˈla(χ)]
    • (Southern Brazil) IPA(key): /kaˈla(ɻ)/
 
  • (Portugal) IPA(key): /kɐˈlaɾ/
  • (Portugal) IPA(key): /kɐˈlaɾ/
    • (Southern Portugal) IPA(key): /kɐˈla.ɾi/

  • Hyphenation: ca‧lar

Verb

[edit]

calar (first-person singular present calo, first-person singular preterite calei, past participle calado)

  1. (pronominal) to shut up (to stop talking)
  2. (transitive) to shut up (to stop someone from talking or something from making noise)
    Synonym: silenciar

Conjugation

[edit]

Future calarei calarás calará calaremos calareis calarão
Conditional calaria calarias calaria calaríamos calaríeis calariam
Subjunctive
Present cale cales cale calemos caleis calem
Imperfect calasse calasses calasse calássemos calásseis calassem
Future calar calares calar calarmos calardes calarem
Imperative
Affirmative cala cale calemos calai calem
Negative (não) não cales não cale não calemos não caleis não calem

1Brazilian Portuguese.
2European Portuguese.

Related terms

[edit]
  • calado
  • calar a boca
  • caluda

Further reading

[edit]

  • “calar”, in Dicionário infopédia da Lingua Portuguesa (in Portuguese), Porto: Porto Editora, 2003–2025

  • “calar”, in Dicionário Priberam da Língua Portuguesa (in Portuguese), Lisbon: Priberam, 2008–2025

Spanish

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /kaˈlaɾ/ [kaˈlaɾ]
  • Rhymes: -aɾ
  • Syllabification: ca‧lar

Etymology 1

[edit]

From cal (“lime”) +‎ -ar, from Latin calx.

Adjective

[edit]

calar m or f (masculine and feminine plural calares)

  1. (relational) limestone, lime
    Synonym: calizo

Noun

[edit]

calar m (plural calares)

  1. limestone quarry
Related terms
[edit]
  • calizo

Etymology 2

[edit]

From Latin chalāre (“to descend”), from Ancient Greek χαλάω (khaláō).

Verb

[edit]

calar (first-person singular present calo, first-person singular preterite calé, past participle calado)

  1. (of a liquid) to soak
    te cala hasta los huesos
    it soaks you to the bone
  2. to pierce with a sharp instrument
  3. (colloquial) to rumble, see through (to discover deceitful or underhanded behavior, hidden true motives or mindset)
  4. to catch on (become fashionable or popular)
  5. (reflexive, Spain) to stall (an engine)
  6. (reflexive) to put on (clothing)
Conjugation
[edit]
    Conjugation of calar (See Appendix:Spanish verbs)
infinitive calar
gerund calando
past participle masculine feminine
singular calado calada
plural calados caladas
singular plural
1st person 2nd person 3rd person 1st person 2nd person 3rd person

imperfect calaba calabas calaba calábamos calabais calaban
preterite calé calaste caló calamos calasteis calaron

conditional calaría calarías calaría calaríamos calaríais calarían
subjunctive yo tú

2Argentine and Uruguayan voseo prefers the tú form for the present subjunctive.
